citation.article-title: Desulfurella multipotens sp. nov. a new sulfur-respiring thermophilic eubacterium from Raoul Island, Kermadec archipelago, New Zealand.

p.s: Description of Desulfurella multipotens sp. nov.
Desulfurella multipotens (mul.ti.po'tens, L.adj. multum many, L.part. potens able, multipotens-having many abilities)
Cells are short rods, 0.5-0.7 by 1.5-1.8 μm, single or in pairs, motile with one polar flagellum.
Cell wall of gram-negative type, with outer S-layer consisting of regularly packed subunits.
On an agar medium with polysulfide, cells form white irregular colonies up to 1 mm in diameter.
Moderate thermophile growing between 42 and 77°C (optimum at 58-60°C) and at a pH from 6.0 to 7.2 (optimum at 6.4-6.8).
Growth substrates: H2/CO2, acetate, pyruvate, butyrate, saturated fatty acids.
Does not utilize formate, propionate, lactate, isobutyrate, caproate, alcohols, carbohydrates, peptides.
Capable oflithoautotrophic growth on mineral medium with H2, CO2, S0.
The G + C content of the DNA is 33.5±2 mol%.
Habitats: hot sediments and cyanobacterial mats, rich in organic matter and elemental sulfur.
Source of isolation: sediments of Green Lake (Raoul Island, Kermadec archipelago, New Zealand).
